bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J.F. Rodriguez-Perez, November 21, 1941

div1.p: Hench discusses the speech he delivered at the unveiling of the latest Cornwell painting and expresses his hope that the event will shed light on the contribution of Finlay in the fight against yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J.F. Rodriguez-Perez, November 21, 1941
div1.opener:
Carbonfor Albertini
& " Molard
November 21, 1941
Dr. J. F. Rodriguez Perez
Director de la Seccion de Publicaciones
Cientificas y Biblioteca Institute Finlay
Habana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Perez:
div1.p:
On September 9 you very kindly advised me that you could not
lend me your copy of “The History of Military Hospital Number One” by
Galliol (1903) but that I might have aphotostatic copy made. Miss Malaret
has told me that I can have it done by the Alabama Photo Studios and I
enclose a copy of a letter I have just written then. I appreciate your
letting them do this for me. I want the whole thing photostated (context,
maps and photographs). I want a good photograph of the old Military
Hospital and realize that the photostatic copies of photographs will not
be good for reproduction but until I see what photographs the book contains
I cannot decide which one to have copied by photography. Will you permit
me to choose from the photostatic copy which one to have photographed and
then later send some photographer around to do it? Of course if there is
only one good photograph of the hospital in Galliol's book I would like
the Alabama Photo Studio to go right ahead and photograph that one photo-
graph (instead of merely photostating it).

Permit me to send you by separate post six reprints of an article
on the conquest of yellow fever which I published recently. I do hope
that you and your colleagues will see in it a beginning of a campaign to
make the American physicians more aware of the greatness of your distinguished
Dr. Finlay and his wonderful work. This painting and this article are a
step in the right direction and I hope to write much more thoroughly on the
subject.

Since I have mentioned Miss Malaret herein I am taking the liberty
of sending her a copy of this letter.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
